label: Description
value: Floral design with large central flower positioned between two large leaves. Other types of flowers and foliage appear including iris blooms. Designed in the art nouveau style, the flowers and leaves gently curve and intertwine creating a dense pattern. Printed in shades of blue on a blue striped background.

label: Provenance
value: 2019, given to Cooper Hewitt by the estate of Don Magner

label: Credit line
value: Gift of Andrew Van Styn from the estate of Don Magner

label: Description
value: In a landscape of rolling terrain, men use birds to hunt wild bulls. Trees frame the composition at left and right, and the hunters appear on horseback in the background at right. Two bulls have fallen in the foreground, while others gallop through the center of the image. The birds—traditionally identified as falcons, although possibly eagles—alight on the heads of their prey, likely blinding them. This hunting method is probably described in an as yet unidentified ancient text.

label: Physical description
value: Pen and brown ink, brush and brown wash, white heightening on buff laid paper

label: Provenance
value: Sotheby's London, Old Master and British Drawings, 8 July 2015 (lot 13); Stephen Ongpin Fine Art, London UK; 2019: acquired by Museum

label: Credit line
value: Museum purchase from the Members' Acquisitions Fund of Cooper Hewitt Smithsonian Design Museum

label: Notes
value: In a landscape of rolling terrain, men use birds to hunt wild bulls. Trees frame the composition at left and right, and the hunters appear on horseback in the background at right. Two bulls have fallen in the foreground, while others gallop through the center of the image. The birds—traditionally identified as falcons, although possibly eagles—alight on the heads of their prey, likely blinding them. label: Description
value: Chinese export blue and white deep bowl, or basin. The central scene of the interior is painted in deep underglaze blue with European court ladies standing on a terrace strewn with flowers, each holding a floral sprig to smell while a servant to one side bears a basket of more flowers. The exterior is decorated with freely painted with floral sprigs.

label: Provenance
value: - 1973: Nijstad Antiquairs (Amsterdam); sold to Ralph M. Chait Gallery (New York). 1973-74: Ralph M. Chait Gallery (New York); sold to private collector (New York). 1974–1981: Private Collection (New York). 1981–2019: Private Collection (New York), by inheritance within the family; sold back to Ralph M. Chait Gallery (New York) 2020: Acquired by Cooper Hewitt

label: Credit line
value: Museum purchase from Charles E. Sampson Memorial Fund

label: Notes
